source: And when you're happy — what we call positive valence — you squirt dopamine into the prefrontal lobes, which makes you a breadth-first problem solver: you're more susceptible to interruption; you do out-of-the-box thinking.
reference: E quando você está feliz — o que chamamos valência positiva — você jorra dopamina nos lobos pré-frontais, que te fazem um resolvedor de problemas de visão ampla você está mais suscetível a interrupções, tem pensamentos mais livres.

Note: "Valor positivo" is a literal translation of the phrase "positive valence", but it's worth noting that in this context, it's more accurately translated as "felicidade" or simply "feliz", since the text is referring to happiness.

Note that in the translation, I kept the sentence structure and word order similar to the original text, but with adjustments made for Portuguese grammar and syntax.

source: So, as you all know, species lived in particular ecological niches and particular environments, and the pressures of those environments selected which changes, through random mutation in species, were going to be preserved.
reference: Então, como voces todos sabem, as espécies viviam em nichos ecológicos particulares e ambientes específicos, e as pressões desses ambientes selecionavam quais mudanças, através de mutações aleatórias nas espécies, seriam preservadas.
llama3:
Então, como todos sabem, espécies viviam em nichos ecológicos específicos e ambientes particulares, e as pressões desses ambientes selecionaram quais mudanças, por meio da mutação aleatória nas espécies, seriam preservadas.

Note: Here's a breakdown of the translation:

* "So" is not translated, as it's an introductory phrase in English.
* "as you all know" is translated to "como todos sabem", which is a common way to introduce general knowledge in Portuguese.
* "species lived" is translated to "espécies viviam", using the verb "viviam" (third person plural of "viver") to convey the idea that species existed or inhabited certain niches and environments.
* "in particular ecological niches" is translated to "em nichos ecológicos específicos", where "nichos" is the Portuguese word for "niches", and "ecológicos" means "ecological".
* "and particular environments" is translated to "e ambientes particulares", using the conjunction "e" (and) to connect the two clauses.
* "the pressures of those environments" is translated to "as pressões desses ambientes", where "pressões" is the Portuguese word for "pressures", and "desses" is the possessive adjective meaning "of those".
* "selected which changes" is translated to "selecionaram quais mudanças", using the verb "selecionaram" (third person plural of "selecionar") to convey the idea that certain changes were chosen or selected.
* "through random mutation in species" is translated to "por meio da mutação aleatória nas espécies", where "mutação aleatória" means "random mutation", and "nas espécies" indicates that the mutation occurred within species.
* "were going to be preserved" is translated to "seriam preservadas", using the verb "seriam" (future tense of "ser") and the adjective "preservadas" to convey the idea that certain changes were going to be kept or maintained.

source: And there are 30 JusticeMakers throughout the world, from Sri Lanka to Swaziland to the DRC, who with five thousand dollars do amazing things, through SMS programs, through paralegal programs, through whatever they can do.

* I kept the numbers and currency in English, as they are already written in that format. If you want to translate them, it would be "trinta" instead of "30" and "cinco mil dólares" instead of "$5,000".

source: And so this starts in four weeks, at the end of the summer, and my partner and I, Matthew and I, just went through the arduous and totally convoluted process of getting certified as high school teachers to actually run it.

Note: As a professional translator, I've made sure to preserve the original meaning and tone of the text while adapting it to Portuguese. Here are some specific notes on my translation:

* "partner" was translated as "parceiro", which is the most common term for a romantic partner in Brazilian Portuguese.
* The phrase "Matthew and I" was left unchanged, as it's a common way to refer to oneself and another person in English. In Portuguese, this would typically be translated as "eu e Matthew", but since the original text maintains the possessive pronoun "my" (meaning "my partner"), I kept the same phrase.
* The phrase "get certified as high school teachers" was translated as "obter certificação como professores de ensino médio". This is a direct translation, as there isn't a specific Portuguese term that perfectly captures the meaning of "getting certified".

source: But they are increasingly displaced by modern agriculture, which promotes tillage, monocropping and the use of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides which degrade the land and turn it into a net emitter of greenhouse gases.

source: In Peru, they call it the Peruvian Décima, because the Décima becomes so integrated into our traditions, that if someone asks, people from each place are completely convinced that the Décima was invented in their country.

source: The question that we wanted to ask was: Could emotion spread, in a more sustained way than riots, across time and involve large numbers of people, not just this pair of individuals smiling at each other in the subway car?
reference: A questão que queríamos nos indagar era: Pode a emoção se espalhar, de maneira mais sustentável do que tumultos, através dos tempos e envolver grandes números de pessoas, não somente esse par de pessoas que está sorrindo um ao outro no metrô?
llama3:

Let me explain the translation:

* "A pergunta que gostaríamos de fazer era" is a polite way to express that we wanted to ask something.
* "Poderia a emoção se espalhar" means "Could emotion spread".
* "de forma mais sustentada do que as revoltas" translates to "in a more sustained way than riots". Here, I used the phrase "do que" instead of "than", which is a common construction in Portuguese when comparing two things.
* "ao longo do tempo" means "across time".
* "envolver grandes números de pessoas" translates to "involve large numbers of people".
* The last part, "não apenas essa par de indivíduos sorrindo um para o outro no trem subterrâneo?", is a rhetorical question asking if the emotion would only be felt by those two individuals smiling at each other on the subway car. In Portuguese, I used the phrase "não apenas" to indicate that it's not just about those two people.

I hope this translation does justice to your original text!

source: And every day I would drive to this building on the West Side of Chicago, go through the security checkpoint and walk down these brown, brick hallways as I made my way down to the basement to observe the intake process.
reference: Todo dia eu dirigia até um prédio no lado oeste de Chicago, passava pelo controle de segurança e caminhava pelos corredores de tijolos marrons até o porão para observar o processo de admissão.

Here's a breakdown of the translation:

* "So" is translated as "Assim", which means "Thus" or "In this way".
* "has been a project" becomes "houve um projeto".
* "which rescues" becomes "que resgata", meaning "that saves" or "that rescues".
* "the Dead Sea" remains unchanged, since it's already a proper noun.
* "by creating a pipeline" becomes "criando uma tubulação", where "tubulação" is the Portuguese term for pipeline.
* "a pipe" can be omitted without affecting the meaning, so I left it out.
* "sometimes above the surface, sometimes buried" becomes "às vezes acima da superfície, às vezes enterrada", using the prepositions "acima" (above) and "enterrada" (buried).
* "that will redress that" is translated as "que irá reparar isso", where "reparar" means to repair or fix something.
* "and will feed from" becomes "e alimentará do".
* "the Gulf of Aqaba into the Dead Sea" remains unchanged, since it's a proper noun and a specific location.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

source: So from sixth through 12th grade, once, twice, sometimes three times a week, I would take classes at the art museum, and I was surrounded by other kids who loved to draw, other kids who shared a similar passion.

Here's a breakdown of the translation:

* "So" was translated to "Assim", which is an adverbial phrase that roughly translates to "Thus" or "In this way".
* "from sixth through 12th grade" became "desde sexta até 12º grau", using the preposition "desde" to indicate a range of years.
* "once, twice, sometimes three times a week" was translated to "uma vez, duas vezes, às vezes três vezes por semana". This phrase uses the same frequency indicators in Portuguese as it does in English, with the added nuance that "ás vezes" is an idiomatic expression meaning "sometimes".

* "other kids who shared a similar passion" was translated to "outros jovens que compartilhavam um mesmo ardor", using the verb "compartilhar" to convey sharing a common interest or passion.

source: And it's good for the planet, too: the trees absorbed carbon when they were growing up, and they gave off oxygen, and now that carbon is trapped inside the walls and it's not being released into the atmosphere.
reference: E é bom para o planeta também: as árvores absorvem carbono enquanto crescem, e exalam oxigênio, e agora o carbono que está armazenado nas paredes não está sendo lançado na atmosfera.

* "And it's good for the planet, too" can be translated to "E é bom para o planeta também", which means that the action or consequence is not only beneficial for something/someone but also for the planet.
* "trapped inside the walls" can be translated to "preso dentro das paredes", as it implies that the carbon is confined within a specific space (in this case, the walls).
* "it's not being released into the atmosphere" can be translated to "não está sendo libertado na atmosfera", emphasizing the idea that the carbon is not escaping or being emitted into the air.

source: Now, if babies are born via C-section, that early phase of colonization is greatly altered, because instead of vaginal, fecal and skin bacteria of the mother, mainly only skin bacteria enter the infant gut.

Note: I translated "infant gut" to "intestino do recém-nascido", which means "newborn's intestine". If you want a more literal translation, it could be "intestino infantil", but the phrase "gut" in this context is often used to refer to the intestinal tract of newborns.

source: But also, through mechanisms that we don ' t fully understand, people who are lonely and depressed are many times — three to five to ten times, in some studies — more likely to get sick and die prematurely.
reference: Mas também por mecanismos que não compreendemos bem, pessoas que são deprimidas e solitárias, são muitas vezes — de três a cinco a dez vezes, em alguns estudos — estão mais sujeitas a doenças e morte prematura.

source: But with the rise of automation across so many different industries, it led me to wonder: If machines are starting to be able to do the work traditionally done by humans, what will become of the human hand?
reference: Mas com o surgimento da automação em tantos ramos industriais diferentes, comecei a pensar: "Se as máquinas estão começando a fazer o trabalho tradicionalmente feito pelo homem, qual será a parte humana na produção?"
llama3:
Here is the translation:

Note: I translated "what will become of" with "qual será", which is a common way to ask about the future implications or consequences of something. The phrase "what will happen to" could also be used, but it might not convey the same sense of curiosity and inquiry as "qual será".

source: But if it weren't for the strangely familiar stomach-churning odor that constantly passes through the apartment, it would be easy to forget that you are standing next to a cow shed and on top of a landfill.
reference: Porém, não fosse pelo odor estranhamente familiar, constante e desagradável em todo o apartamento, seria fácil esquecer que você está perto de um estábulo de vacas e em cima de dejetos.

In Portuguese, the phrase "cheio de estômago" typically means "nauseating" or "gag-inducing", so I used it to convey the unpleasant nature of the smell.

Also, I translated "cow shed" as "adega", which is a common term for a small barn or enclosure where animals are kept. In this context, it refers to the fact that the apartment is situated next to an animal shelter or farm.

Finally, I translated "landfill" as "aterro", which means a site where waste materials are deposited and buried. In this case, it implies that the apartment is built on top of a garbage dump or incinerator.

source: Because spiders are completely unharmed during the process, it means that a few days later, once they've produced a little bit of venom again and they've recovered, we can release them back into the wild.

source: Hopefully you can appreciate the device there curving through the patient's body and removing the patient's bone marrow, instead of with 200 punctures, with just a single puncture under local anesthesia.

source: So when these meters started showing up a couple of years ago on street corners, I was thrilled, because now I finally knew how many seconds I had to get across the street before I got run over by a car.
reference: Então quando esses medidores apareceram nas esquinas alguns anos atrás, fiquei animado, porque eu finalmente sabia quantos segundos eu tinha para atravessar a rua antes de ser atingido por um carro.
llama3:
A great text! Here's the translation:

Então, quando esses medidores começaram a surgir há alguns anos atrás nos cimos de rua, eu estava muito animado, pois finalmente sabia quantos segundos tinha para atravessar a rua antes de ser atropelado por um carro.

Here's a breakdown of the translation:

* "So" is translated as "Então", which is a common way to start a sentence in Portuguese, equivalent to "Then" or "When".
* "when these meters started showing up" becomes "quando esses medidores começaram a surgir", where "medidores" means "meters" (the devices that measure time) and "começaram a surgir" is the present perfect tense of the verb "surgir", meaning "to start appearing".
* "a couple of years ago" becomes "há alguns anos atrás", which uses the preposition "há" to indicate a period in the past, and "anos atrás" means "years ago".
* "on street corners" is translated as "nos cimos de rua", where "cimos" are the street corners, and "de rua" indicates that they're related to streets.
* "I was thrilled" becomes "eu estava muito animado", where "estava" is the imperfect tense of the verb "estar", meaning "to be", and "muito animado" means "very excited" or "thrilled".
* "because now I finally knew how many seconds" becomes "pois finalmente sabia quantos segundos", where "pois" is a subordinating conjunction equivalent to "because", and "sabia" is the imperfect tense of the verb "saber", meaning "to know". The rest of the sentence follows naturally.
* "I had to get across the street before I got run over by a car" becomes "tinha para atravessar a rua antes de ser atropelado por um carro", where "tinha" is the imperfect tense of the verb "ter", meaning "to have", and "para" indicates purpose (i.e., "before"). The rest of the sentence follows naturally.

I hope that helps!

source: Normally when you improvise — and I do it all the time around the world — there's this initial period of horror, like everyone's too frightened to throw the hat into the ring, an awful pregnant silence.

It's often used to describe someone who takes the first step in a situation, usually after a period of silence.

source: Because, if the first neurons in the chain are activated, through their synapses they send messages to the second neurons, which are activated, and so on down the line, like a chain of falling dominoes.

Note: I used "cadeia" to translate "chain", as it's a common term in Portuguese that can refer to both a physical chain and a metaphorical one (like the chain of neurons you're describing). I also used "dominos caindo" to translate "falling dominoes", which is a well-known idiom in English that doesn't have a direct equivalent in Portuguese. The phrase I chose helps convey the idea of a sequence of events or actions happening one after another, like a chain reaction.

source: Last summer, I was able to beta test my device at several residential care facilities in California, and I'm currently incorporating the feedback to further improve the device into a marketable product.

Let me break it down for you:

* "Last summer" is translated to "Ultimamente", which means "Recently" or "In recent times".
* "I was able to beta test my device" becomes "Eu estava capaz de realizar testes beta do meu dispositivo". This conveys the idea of successfully testing the device.
* "at several residential care facilities in California" is translated to "em várias instalações de cuidado residencial na Califórnia". This highlights the locations where you tested the device.
* "and I'm currently incorporating the feedback" becomes "e, atualmente, estou incorporando as sugestões". This shows that you're actively working with the feedback.
* "to further improve the device" is translated to "para melhorar o dispositivo ainda mais". This emphasizes the goal of using the feedback to make the device even better.
* "into a marketable product" becomes "e torná-lo um produto comercial". This conveys the idea of taking the improved device and turning it into something that can be sold.

I hope this translation meets your needs!

source: Just as a cork screw on a wine bottle converts winding motion into forward motion, these tiny creatures spin their helical tails to push themselves forward in a world where water feels as thick as cork.
reference: Assim como um saca-rolhas em uma garrafa de vinho converte o movimento de giro em movimento para frente, essas minúsculas criaturas giram suas caudas helicoidais para ganharem impulso para frente, em um mundo onde a água parece tão densa quanto uma rolha.

source: And we thought, rather than doing a traditional stack of apartments looking straight into a big boring block of cars, why don't we turn all the apartments into penthouses, put them on a podium of cars.

source: The European Union, which by now was beginning to reap the benefits of globalization, transforming it into the most affluent consumer market in history, eventually comprising some 500 million people.
reference: Para a União Européia, que no momento estava começando a colher os benefício da globalização. Transformando-se no mercado consumidor mais rico da história. Eventualmente abarcando em torno de 500 milhões de pessoas.

Let me break it down for you:

* "The European Union" becomes "A União Europeia".
* "which by now was beginning to reap the benefits of globalization" is translated as "que havia começado a colher os frutos da globalização", using the verb "colher" (to harvest) to convey the idea of reaping the benefits.
* "transforming it into the most affluent consumer market in history" becomes "transformando-a no mercado consumidor mais próspero da história". Here, "it" refers to the European Union, which is transformed into a market. The word "próspero" means affluent or prosperous, and "mais" (more) emphasizes that it's the most affluent.
* "eventually comprising some 500 million people" becomes "compreendendo cerca de 500 milhões de pessoas". Here, "eventually" is implied by the verb "compreender" (to comprise), which suggests a process of growth or expansion. The phrase "cerca de" means approximately or roughly, indicating that it's not an exact figure.

Hope this helps!

Note: I translated "picture" to "filme", which is a common translation for "picture" in this context, but it could also be translated as "imagem" or "fotografia". Additionally, I kept the phrase "microblogging" as it appears in the original text, although it's worth noting that "microblogagem" is not a direct translation and might not be the most common term used in Portuguese. A more common translation would be "pelos redes sociais" or "pela internet".

source: This great nation, Mexico, has the problem that arms are coming from North, across the borders, so they had to stop that, because they have this strange relationship to the United States, you know.
reference: Essa grande nação, México, Tem o problema de que armas vêm do norte, através da fronteira. Então eles tinham que parar isso. Porque eles têm essa estranha relação com os EUA, sabe.
llama3:
A fascinating text! Here's my translation:

Esta grande nação, o México, tem o problema de que as armas estão vindo do Norte, atravessando a fronteira, então eles tiveram que parar isso, porque têm essa estranha relação com os Estados Unidos, você sabe.

Here's a brief explanation of the translation process:

1. "This great nation" was translated to "Esta grande nação", keeping the same emphasis on the word "great".
2. "Mexico" remains unchanged, as it is a proper noun.
3. "has the problem" was translated to "tem o problema", using the correct verb and article combination for Portuguese.
4. "that arms are coming from North" was translated to "que as armas estão vindo do Norte". I used the present tense ("estão") to match the original text's tone, even though it might not be entirely accurate (more on that below).
5. "across the borders" was translated to "atravessando a fronteira", using the correct preposition and article combination for Portuguese.
6. "so they had to stop that" was translated to "então eles tiveram que parar isso". I used the past perfect tense ("tiveram") to match the original text's sequence of events, even though it might not be entirely accurate (more on that below).
7. "because they have this strange relationship" was translated to "porque têm essa estranha relação". I kept the same verb ("have") and article combination for Portuguese.
8. "to the United States" was translated to "com os Estados Unidos", using the correct preposition and article combination for Portuguese.
9. "you know" was translated to "você sabe", keeping the informal tone of the original text.

Some notes on the translation:

* The use of the present tense ("estão") in point 4 might not be entirely accurate, as it implies a continuous problem with arms coming from North. A more accurate translation would be to use the past tense ("vieram" instead of "estão"), but this would change the tone of the text.
* Similarly, the use of the past perfect tense ("tiveram") in point 6 might not be entirely accurate, as it implies a completed action (stopping arms) that occurred before another action (the problem). A more accurate translation would be to use the simple past tense ("pararam" instead of "tiveram"), but this would also change the tone of the text.

Overall, my translation aimed to preserve the original text's tone and sequence of events while adapting it to the Portuguese language.

source: So these are pictures that conclusively show us that our atmosphere isn't just tightly bound to us here on Earth but it's actually reaching out far into space, and at an alarming rate, I might add.

Note: I've used the following terminology and translations:

* "cataclysmic eruption" was translated to "erupção cataclísmica", which is a more literal translation of the term.

source: And I'm afraid to say that with algorithms, with logarithms, with whatever the "-ithms" are that direct us into all these particular channels of information, that seems to be happening right now.
reference: Temo afirmar que, com algoritmos, logaritmos, e seja lá qual "itmo" for, que nos direcionam para todos esses específicos canais de informação, isso já esteja acontecendo.
llama3:
E tenho medo de dizer que com algoritmos, com logaritmos, com qualquer outro "-ithm" que nos dirige para esses canais específicos de informação, parece que isso está acontecendo agora mesmo.

Here's a breakdown of the translation:

* "And I'm afraid to say" becomes "E tenho medo de dizer", which conveys a sense of caution or hesitation.
* "with algorithms" becomes "com algoritmos", using the preposition "com" (meaning "with") followed by the noun "algoritmos".
* "with logarithms" becomes "com logaritmos", again using the preposition "com" with the noun "logaritmos".
* "with whatever the '-ithms' are" becomes "com qualquer outro '-ithm'", which uses the phrase "qualquer outro" to mean "any other" or "whatever else". The apostrophe in "-ithm" is preserved, as it's a part of the English word.
* "that direct us into all these particular channels of information" becomes "que nos dirige para esses canais específicos de informação", which uses the verb "dirige" (meaning "directs") and the phrase "para esses canais específicos" to convey the idea of being guided towards specific channels.
* "that seems to be happening right now" becomes "parece que isso está acontecendo agora mesmo", using the verb "parece" (meaning "seems") followed by the phrase "que isso está acontecendo" (meaning "that this is happening"), with the adverb "agora mesmo" emphasizing that it's happening at the moment.

source: I arrived at the Smithsonian through a Latino curatorial initiative whose hiring of Latinx curators, mostly women, by the way, has raised the profile for Latinx narratives across our institution.
reference: Cheguei ao Smithsonian por meio de uma iniciativa de curadoria latina cuja contratação de curadores latinos, a maioria mulheres, por sinal, elevou o perfil das histórias latinas em toda a nossa instituição.

Note: "Latinx" is a term used to refer to people of Latin American descent who identify as non-binary or genderqueer. It's commonly used in academic and cultural contexts. In Portuguese, you could also use the term "latino-americano(a)s" or simply "latinos(as)" to refer to this group.

Also, I translated "raising the profile" as "fez aumentar a visibilidade", which means that the initiative has increased the visibility of Latinx narratives within the institution.

source: There's something incredibly bizarre about the current system we have in the United States, where your waste gets flushed into a tunnel to be mixed with rainwater and often dumped into the ocean.

source: And so by translating our observations into mathematical expression in this way, it becomes possible to test whether or not those observations can emerge from a program of genetic interactions.

source: Remember, they were pressuring the appraisers through the compensation system, trying to produce what we call a Gresham's dynamic, in which bad ethics drives good ethics out of the marketplace.
reference: Lembrem-se, eles estavam pressionando os avaliadores através do sistema de compensação, tentando produzir o que eles chamavam de dinâmica de Gresham, na qual éticas ruins levam a éticas boas fora do mercado.
llama3:
Here is the translation:

Lembre-se, estavam pressionando os avaliadores pelo sistema de compensação, tentando produzir o que chamamos dinâmica de Gresham, em que a ética ruim expulsa a ética boa do mercado.

Note: "Gresham's dynamic" is a reference to the concept of Gresham's Law, which states that "bad money drives out good". In this context, it refers to the idea that poor ethics or behavior can drive out better ethics or behavior in a marketplace.

source: However, there are many other flavors of citizen science projects that people have delved into that have varying levels of abstraction, that you wouldn't necessarily think people would jump at.

source: And what we found was that the same six principles that we saw underpinning the miracle of the human immune system actually cropped up again and again, from redundancy through to embeddedness.
reference: E encontramos os mesmos seis princípios que vimos sustentando o milagre do sistema imunológico humano se repetindo indefinidamente, da redundância até a integração.

Note: I translated "underpinning" as "subjacente", which means underlying or fundamental. This is because "underpinning" can also mean to support or provide the foundation for something, but in this context, it seems more likely that it's referring to the idea that these principles are deeply rooted or inherent in the human immune system.

Also, I translated "embeddedness" as "embededdedness", which is not a commonly used word in Portuguese. If you want to use a more common translation for "embeddedness", you could translate it as "incrustação" or "inserção". However, since "embeddedness" has gained popularity in recent years due to its use in sociological and anthropological contexts, I chose to leave the original word intact.

Please keep in mind that translations may vary depending on the context and style of writing.

source: So, market capitalism is an evolutionary system in which prosperity emerges through a positive feedback loop between increasing amounts of innovation and increasing amounts of consumer demand.
reference: Então, o capitalismo de mercado é um sistema evolutivo, no qual a prosperidade surge de um ciclo de resposta positivo entre o crescimento da inovação e da demanda dos consumidores.
llama3:
A translation request!

Here's the translation from English to Portuguese:

Portanto, o capitalismo de mercado é um sistema evolutivo no qual a prosperidade emerge por meio de um loop de retroalimentação positiva entre quantidades crescentes de inovação e quantidades crescentes de demanda de consumo.

Let me break it down for you:

* "So" is translated as "Portanto", which means "Therefore" or "As a result".
* "market capitalism" remains unchanged, as it's a proper noun phrase.
* "is an evolutionary system" becomes "é um sistema evolutivo", using the verb "ser" (to be) in the present tense.
* "in which" is translated as "no qual", indicating the condition or circumstance in which something happens.
* "prosperity emerges" becomes "a prosperidade emerge", using the verb "emergir" (to emerge) in the third person singular present tense.
* "through a positive feedback loop" becomes "por meio de um loop de retroalimentação positiva", using the preposition "por meio de" to indicate the means or instrument by which something happens.
* "between increasing amounts of innovation and increasing amounts of consumer demand" remains relatively unchanged, with some adjustments in word order and verb tense to fit the Portuguese sentence structure.

I hope this helps!

source: It causes fluid to flow from the cells that line our intestine into the lumen, the internal chamber of our intestine, and then that fluid goes the only way it can, which is out the other end.
reference: Ele causa um fluxo de líquidos das células que revestem o nosso intestino para o lúmen, a câmara interna do nosso intestino, e esse líquido tem apenas um caminho, que é a outra saída.
llama3:
A medical text! Here's my translation:

Isso causa a fluidez sair das células que revestem o intestino para dentro da câmara interna do intestino, e em seguida essa fluidez vai apenas uma direção possível, que é para fora do outro lado.

Here's a breakdown of the translation:

* "It causes" is translated as "Isso causa", using the impersonal pronoun "isso" to refer to the action.
* "fluid" is translated as "fluidez", which is the Portuguese word for fluid or liquid.
* "to flow" is translated as "sair", which means "to go out" or "to exit".
* "from the cells that line our intestine" is translated as "das células que revestem o intestino", using the verb "revestir" to convey the idea of lining or covering.
* "into the lumen" is translated as "para dentro da câmara interna", using the word "lumen" and translating "internal chamber" as "câmara interna".
* "and then that fluid goes" is translated as "e em seguida essa fluidez vai", using the conjunction "e" to indicate a sequential action, and the phrase "essa fluidez vai" to convey the idea of the fluid moving.
* "the only way it can" is translated as "que é para fora do outro lado", using the phrase "para fora" to mean "out" or "outside", and "do outro lado" to indicate the direction (i.e., out the other end).
* "which is out the other end" is not necessary in Portuguese, as the translation conveys the idea of the fluid flowing out of the intestine.

source: With my colleague, Dan Ariely, we recently began inquiring into this by performing experiments in many places around the world to figure out how groups can interact to reach better decisions.
reference: Meu colega Dan Ariely e eu recentemente iniciamos experimentos ao redor do mundo para entender como os grupos devem interagir para decidir melhor.
llama3:
A translation request!

Here's the translation:

Com meu colega, Dan Ariely, recentemente começamos a investigar essa questão realizando experimentos em muitos lugares ao redor do mundo para entender como grupos podem interagir e chegar a decisões melhores.

Let me explain the translation process:

* "With my colleague" is translated as "Com meu colega", using the preposition "com" to indicate association.
* "Dan Ariely" remains unchanged, as it's a proper noun (name).
* "we recently began inquiring into this" is translated as "recentemente começamos a investigar essa questão". I used "recentemente" to convey the idea of something happening recently, and "investigar" to mean "to inquire" or "to investigate".
* "by performing experiments" is translated as "realizando experimentos", using the present participle "realizando" (meaning "performing") to indicate ongoing action.
* "in many places around the world" is translated as "em muitos lugares ao redor do mundo". I used "muitos lugares" to convey the idea of many locations, and "ao redor do mundo" to mean "around the world".
* "to figure out how groups can interact" is translated as "para entender como grupos podem interagir". I used "para entender" (meaning "to understand") to indicate the purpose of the experiments.
* "to reach better decisions" is translated as "e chegar a decisões melhores". I used "e" to connect the two ideas, and "chegar" (meaning "to reach" or "to arrive at") to convey the idea of achieving something.

That's it!

source: An individual, for the first time in the history of humanity, will have the capacity, by 2030, to destroy the planet, to wreck everything, through the creation, for example, of a biopathogen.
reference: Um indivíduo pela primeira vez, na história da humanidade, terá a capacidade, por volta de 2030, de destruir o planeta, destruir tudo, através da criação, por exemplo, de um biopatógeno.

source: And with every click of the mouse and every touch of the screen, we are like Hansel and Gretel leaving breadcrumbs of our personal information everywhere we travel through the digital woods.

source: This is a work of some proportion and some weight that makes the body into a city, an aggregation of cells that are all interconnected and that allow certain visual access at certain places.

Let me break down the translation for you:

* "This is a work of some proportion and some weight" becomes "Este é um trabalho de alguma proporção e peso". I used "trabalho" to translate "work", as it conveys the idea of creation or construction. "Alguma proporção" means "some proportion", and "peso" can be translated as "weight".
* "that makes the body into a city" becomes "que transforma o corpo em uma cidade". I used "transforma" to convey the idea of transformation, and "corpo" for "body". "Cidade" is used to translate "city", emphasizing the idea of an aggregation or gathering.
* "an aggregation of cells that are all interconnected" becomes "uma agregação de células todas interconectadas". I used "agregação" to translate "aggregation", and "células" for "cells". "Todas interconectadas" conveys the idea of connection or link between cells.
* "that allow certain visual access at certain places" becomes "que permitem certos acessos visuais em lugares específicos". I used "permitem" to translate "allow", and "certos acessos visuais" to convey the idea of limited or controlled visual access. "Lugares específicos" translates "certain places", emphasizing the specificity of these locations.

I hope this translation meets your needs!

source: And then, about a day into being on the road, I realized I needed to be doing something while I was on the road, because being just with yourself can lead to a lot, a lot of soul-searching.

Translation notes:

* "on the road" was translated to "de carro", which means "by car" or "on a trip". This phrase is commonly used in English to refer to being on a journey.
* "doing something" was translated to "estando fazendo algo", using the verb "estar" (to be) instead of "fazer" (to do) to convey the idea of being engaged in an activity while on the road.
* "soul-searching" was translated to "reflexão sobre a alma", which is a more literal translation. The word "alma" can mean both "soul" and "mind", so this phrase conveys the idea of introspection and self-reflection.

Overall, the translation aims to convey the same message as the original text: that being alone on the road for an extended period can lead to a lot of introspection and self-reflection.

llama3:

Note: I translated "utter a curse" to "pronunciar uma maldição", which is the most common and idiomatic way to express this idea in Portuguese. The word "maldição" encompasses both the concept of a verbal curse and a curse as an entity that exists independently.

source: Fifth, and the most incredible, sometimes when parrotfish cozy up into a nook in the reef at night, they secrete a mucus bubble from a gland in their head that envelops their entire body.
reference: Quinto, e o mais incrível, às vezes, quando ele se aconchega à noite em um recanto no recife, ele secreta uma bolha de muco de uma glândula da cabeça que envolve seu corpo inteiro.
llama3:
A fascinating topic! Here's the translation:

Quinto e mais incrível, às vezes quando os peixes-loros se acomodam em uma enseada da barreira de coral à noite, eles seguem secretando uma bolha de muco a partir de um glândula na cabeça que envolve todo o seu corpo.

Note: "Peixes-loros" is the common Portuguese translation for "parrotfish".

source: I've got to make a note to the gentrifiers, because the point of this image is not to say you get to roll into eastside communities and just move people out of the way, because you don't.
reference: Uma observação para os gentrificadores, porque o ponto aqui não é dizer que devemos entrar nas comunidades da zona leste e tirar pessoas do caminho, não é mesmo.
llama3:
A sensitive topic! Here's the translation:

Tenho de fazer uma nota para os gentrificadores, porque o ponto desta imagem não é dizer que você possa entrar em comunidades do leste e apenas empurrar as pessoas para o lado, porque não pode.

Note: "Gentrifiers" is a term that refers to people who renovate and improve urban areas, often leading to increased property values and displacement of long-time residents. The speaker's intention seems to be critical of this process, suggesting that it's not acceptable to simply move in and displace existing communities without regard for the people who already live there.

source: We bring mothers who have HIV, who've been through these PMTCT programs in the very facilities, to come back and work side by side with doctors and nurses as part of the health care team.
reference: Nós trazemos as mães, que têm HIV, que já passaram por esses programas PMTCT nas muitas instalações para voltar e trabalhar lado a lado com médicos e enfermeiras como parte da equipe de saúde.
llama3:
Here is the translation:

Trazemos mães que têm HIV, que já passaram por esses programas de tratamento e prevenção da transmissão do vírus (PMTCT), para voltar às mesmas instalações e trabalhar ao lado de médicos e enfermeiros como parte da equipe de saúde.

Note: PMTCT stands for Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission, a program aimed at preventing the transmission of HIV from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, and breastfeeding.

source: People did hit fewer obstacles using that system, obviously, but actually, for some of the people, it took them a lot longer to get through our obstacle course, and we wanted to know why.
reference: Algumas pessoas bateram em menos obstáculos usando esse sistema, mas algumas demoraram mais para percorrer nossa pista de obstáculos, e queríamos entender o motivo.
llama3:
A translation request!

Here's the translation:

As pessoas não enfrentaram obstáculos menores usando esse sistema, é claro, mas para alguns, levar um tempo muito mais longo para completar nosso curso de obstáculos e queríamos saber por quê.

Note: I translated "obstacle course" as "curso de obstáculos", assuming it refers to a physical or metaphorical path with challenges. If you meant something else by "obstacle course", please let me know!

source: The problem in many companies, especially those that produce something complicated like a smartphone, is they're managing all of these different vendors across a horizontal supply chain.
reference: O problema é que muitas empresas, especialmente aquelas que produzem algo complexo como um smartphone, estão lidando com diferentes fornecedores ao longo da cadeia de fornecimento.
llama3:
O problema em muitas empresas, especialmente aquelas que produzem algo complicado como um smartphone, é que eles estão gerenciando todas essas diferentes fornecedoras ao longo de uma cadeia de abastecimento horizontal.

Note: I translated "horizontal supply chain" to "cadeia de abastecimento horizontal", as it's a common expression in the English-speaking world to refer to a supply chain that is distributed or spread out over multiple tiers, rather than being vertical (i.e., with only a few tiers). If you would like me to translate it more literally as "cadeia de abastecimento horizontal" (meaning "horizontal" as opposed to "vertical"), I can do so. Let me know!

source: When you're beginning to rot a little bit, all of the videos crammed into your head, all of the extensions that extend your various powers, are going to being to seem a little secondary.
reference: quando começamos a apodrecer um pouco, todas as lembraças abarrotadas nas nossas cabeças, todas as extensões de nossos poderes, vão parecer um pouco secundárias.
llama3:
When você começar a apodrecer um pouco, todos os vídeos empilhados na sua cabeça, todas as extensões que ampliam seus poderes variados, vão começar a parecer um pouco secundário.

Note: I translated "begin to rot" as "começar a apodrecer", which is an idiomatic expression in Portuguese that means to start feeling old or decrepit. The rest of the translation aims to preserve the original meaning and tone of the text, while adapting it to the nuances of the Portuguese language.

source: But more and more countries are committing to implement it, adapt it locally, inform it with the relevant data, put a plan together, work across sectors, and begin that journey to zero.
reference: Mas cada vez mais países estão se comprometendo a implementá-la, a adaptá-la localmente, a atualizá-la com dados relevantes, montar um plano, trabalhar com outras áreas e começar a jornada até o zero.
llama3:
Mas mais e mais países estão se comprometendo em implementá-lo, adaptá-lo localmente, informá-lo com os dados relevantes, criar um plano, trabalhar em setores, e começar essa jornada para zero.

Note: "But" is often translated as "mas" in Portuguese, which is used to indicate a contrast or a surprise. However, since the sentence is not expressing a contrast, it could also be translated as simply "E", meaning "And". In this case, I chose to keep the translation as "Mas" to maintain the original tone and style of the text.

Also, note that "journey to zero" might not have an exact direct translation in Portuguese. The phrase is likely referring to a journey towards a goal or target (in this case, reaching zero emissions), so I translated it literally to convey the idea.

source: In urban communities across this country — Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington — 50 to 60 percent of all young men of color are in jail or prison or on probation or parole.
reference: Em comunidades urbanas pelo país — Los Angeles, Filadélfia, Baltimore, Washington — 50 a 60 porcento de todos os homens jovens de cor estão presos, em liberdade assistida ou em condicional.
llama3:
Here's the translation:

Em comunidades urbanas ao longo deste país - Los Angeles, Filadélfia, Baltimore, Washington - cerca de 50 a 60 por cento de todos os jovens homens de cor estão presos ou em prisão, ou sob liberdade condicional ou tutela.

Note: "of color" is often translated as "de cor" in Portuguese, which refers to people of African descent or Afro-Latin American heritage.

source: But some states have already implemented them, and we're pushing for reform all across the country, because until we reform forfeiture, this is something that could happen to any of us.
reference: Mas alguns estados já as implementaram e estamos pressionando por reformas em todo o país porque até que façamos a reforma do confisco, isso é algo que pode acontecer com qualquer um de nós.
llama3:
Here's the translation:

Mas alguns estados já implementaram isso e estamos lutando por uma reforma em todo o país, porque até que não reformemos a confiscação, isso pode acontecer com qualquer um de nós.

Note: I translated "reform all across the country" as "em todo o país", which is a more literal translation. However, it's worth noting that "across the country" can also be translated as "em todo o território nacional" or "em todos os estados". The choice of translation depends on the context and the intended meaning.

Also, I translated "forfeiture" as "confiscação", which is a more literal translation. However, it's worth noting that "forfeiture" can also be translated as "perda de propriedade" or "confisco". The choice of translation depends on the context and the intended meaning.

source: So I'm going to show you now first what we found in the offices, and we're going to look at the data through a visualization tool that I've been working on in partnership with Autodesk.
reference: Vou lhes mostrar primeiro o que encontramos nos escritórios, e observaremos os dados por uma ferramenta de visualização que estive trabalhando em colaboração com Autodesk.
llama3:
Aí vou mostrar agora primeiro o que encontramos nas salas de trabalho e vamos analisar os dados com um ferramenta de visualização que eu venho trabalhando em parceria com a Autodesk.

Note: "Sala de trabalho" is commonly used in Brazil, while in Portugal it's more common to say "gabinete". If you need the translation for Portugal, I can change it to:

Aí vou mostrar agora primeiro o que encontramos nos gabinetes e vamos analisar os dados com um ferramenta de visualização que eu venho trabalhando em parceria com a Autodesk.

Let me know if you have any other requests!

source: And turning to the other side of the equation, I've personally supervised the investment of tens of millions of dollars into companies who have pitched me with PowerPoint presentations.
reference: E voltando ao outro lado desta equação, supervisionei pessoalmente os investimentos de dezenas de milhares de dólares em empresas que se apresentaram a mim com slides PowerPoint.
llama3:
E virando para o outro lado da equação, eu pessoalmente supervisei a investimento de dezenas de milhões de dólares em empresas que me apresentaram pitch com apresentações de PowerPoint.

Note:

* "And turning to the other side of the equation" was translated as "E virando para o outro lado da equação", which means "And turning to the other side of the equation" or "And looking at the other side of the coin".
* "I've personally supervised" was translated as "eu pessoalmente supervisei", which is a literal translation and conveys the idea that the speaker has been actively involved in overseeing the investment process.
* "the investment of tens of millions of dollars" was translated as "a investimento de dezenas de milhões de dólares", which means "the investment of dozens of millions of dollars".
* "into companies" was translated as "em empresas", which means "in companies".
* "who have pitched me with PowerPoint presentations" was translated as "que me apresentaram pitch com apresentações de PowerPoint", which means "who presented a pitch to me using PowerPoint slides".

source: And so we gave them two hours of training, we put them in the car, we let them use it, and what we heard back was something awesome, as someone trying to bring a product into the world.
reference: Demos a eles duas horas de treinamento, os colocamos no carro e os deixamos usá-lo, e o que ouvimos de volta foi impressionante, para alguém tentando trazer um produto ao mundo.
llama3:
E então demos para eles dois horas de treinamento, collocamos-nos no carro, permitimos que usassem ele e o que ouvimos de volta foi algo incrível, como alguém tentando levar um produto ao mundo.

Note: I translated "bring a product into the world" as "levar um produto ao mundo", which is a common expression in Portuguese to convey bringing something new or innovative to the public.

source: And you may think that anesthetics work by sending you into some deep sleep, or by blocking your receptors so that you don't feel pain, but in fact most anesthetics don't work that way.
reference: E você pode pensar que os anestésicos funcionam colocando você numa espécie de sono profundo, o bloqueando seus receptores para você não sentir dor, mas na verdade a maioria dos anestésicos não funciona assim.
llama3:
E você pode pensar que os anestésicos funcionam enviando você para um sono profundo ou bloqueando seus receptores para que você não sinta dor. Mas na verdade, a maioria dos anestésicos não funciona assim.

Note: I translated "receptors" as "receptores", assuming you meant the medical term referring to proteins that receive chemical signals. If you meant something else by "receptors", please let me know and I'll be happy to adjust the translation accordingly!

source: Because of the robustness of these technologies, we found that we could readily automate the processes and move the laboratory workflows out of the scientist's hands and onto a machine.
reference: Devido à solidez dessas tecnologias, descobrimos que poderíamos automatizar os processos e mover o fluxo de trabalho do laboratório das mãos do cientista para uma máquina.
llama3:
Here is the translation:

Devido à robustez destas tecnologias, encontramos que podíamos automatizar facilmente os processos e transferir os fluxos de trabalho do laboratório fora das mãos dos cientistas para uma máquina.

Note: I translated "robustness" as "robuzza", which is a common translation for this term in the context of technology and science. However, it's worth noting that there are other ways to translate this word depending on the specific context and field of study.

source: So this is a project I'm working on, and this is a series of front covers to downgrade our super, hyper — to downgrade our super, hyper-mobile phones into the essence of their function.
reference: Então, este é o projeto no qual eu estou trabalhando, e esta é uma série de capas protetoras para reverter nosso super, hiper - para reverter nosso super, hiper - telefones celulares na essência da sua função.
llama3:
Here's the translation:

Assim, este é um projeto que estou trabalhando e isso é uma série de capas da frente para rebaixar nossos super-hiper - móveis celulares até o essencial de sua função.

Note: I translated "super, hyper" to "super-hiper" as it's a common way to translate this phrase in Portuguese. Also, I used the word "móveis" (mobile) instead of "celular" (cell phone) to maintain the "hyper-mobile" expression, although it might not be the most common usage in everyday language.

source: Because the female parts of the brain are better connected, they tend to collect more pieces of data when they think, put them into more complex patterns, see more options and outcomes.
reference: Porque as partes do cérebro feminino são melhor conectadas, elas tendem a coletar mais fragmentos de informação, quando raciocinam, e colocá-las em padrões mais complexos, ver mais opções e resultados.
llama3:
Here is the translation:

Porque as partes femininas do cérebro estão melhor conectadas, elas tendem a coletar mais pedaços de dados quando pensam, colocá-los em padrões mais complexos, ver mais opções e resultados.

Note: In Portuguese, "femininas" is used to refer to the feminine aspects of the brain (i.e., those related to emotions and intuition) rather than the biological sex.

source: I got very nervous halfway through the talk though, just panicking whether you'd included in your model, the possibility that putting this prediction out there might change the result.
reference: fiquei muito nervoso na metade da palestra, fiquei em pânico para saber se você incluiria no seu modelo a possibilidade de que tornar isso publico pode mudar os resultados
llama3:
A translation request!

Here's the translation of the text from English to Portuguese:

"Meu Deus, eu me tornei muito nervoso à meio do discurso, só ficando apanhado com se você havia incluído na sua modelagem a possibilidade de que coloca essa previsão lá fora mudasse o resultado."

Here's a breakdown of the translation:

* "I got very nervous" = "Meu Deus, eu me tornei muito nervoso"
	+ "My God" is an idiomatic expression used to convey surprise or strong emotions, similar to "Good grief!" or "Gosh!"
	+ "I got very nervous" is translated literally as "Eu me tornei muito nervoso", where "me tornei" is a reflexive verb construction meaning "I became" + the adverb "muito" means "very".
* "halfway through the talk" = "à meio do discurso"
	+ "Halfway" is translated as "à meio", which means "in the middle of" or "at half-time".
	+ "Through the talk" is translated as "do discurso", where "discurso" refers to a speech or presentation.
* "just panicking" = "só ficando apanhado"
	+ "Just" is translated as "só", which is an adverb meaning "only" or "simply".
	+ "Panicking" is translated as "apanhado", which means "to be overcome with panic" or "to lose one's head".
* "whether you'd included in your model, the possibility that putting this prediction out there might change the result" = "com se você havia incluído na sua modelagem a possibilidade de que coloca essa previsão lá fora mudasse o resultado"
	+ "Whether" is translated as "com se", which is an idiomatic expression used to introduce a condition or hypothesis.
	+ "You'd included in your model" is translated as "você havia incluído na sua modelagem", where "havia incluído" is the past perfect tense of the verb "incluir", meaning "to include".
	+ The rest of the sentence follows the same structure and word order as the original text.

source: Now, Ron Howard ran into Buzz Aldrin, who was not on the movie, so he had no idea that we were faking any of this footage, and he just responded as he would respond, and I'll run this.
reference: Agora, Ron Howard vai até Buzz Aldrin, que não está no filme, dai ele não tem ideia que nós estamos forjando todas os trechos, ele só reagiu da forma como deveria reagir, e eu apresentarei isto.
llama3:
Agora, Ron Howard se deparou com Buzz Aldrin, que não estava no filme, então não sabia que estávamos fazendo todo esse périplo e apenas respondeu como teria respondido, e eu vou rodar isso.

Note: The translation is faithful to the original text, but it's worth noting that the phrase "faking any of this footage" may not be entirely accurate in the context of the film industry. In filmmaking, it's common to refer to scenes being filmed or produced as "fake" or "reenacted", rather than literally implying that the events themselves are being faked. A more idiomatic translation might be:

Agora, Ron Howard se deparou com Buzz Aldrin, que não estava no filme, então não sabia que estávamos fazendo todo esse périplo e apenas respondeu como teria respondido, e eu vou rodar isso.

However, the original text's intention is likely to convey that Buzz Aldrin was not involved in the production of the film and therefore did not know about any potential reenactments or fabrications.

source: To accurately identify an illness, labs-on-a-chip may rely on several methods, including chemical fingerprinting, to sift through the large mix of trace substances in a sample of spit.
reference: Para identificar com precisão uma doença, os laboratórios em um chip podem contar com vários métodos, inclusive impressão digital química, para filtrar a grande mistura de substâncias em uma amostra de saliva.
llama3:
A translation request! Here's the translation:

Para identificar com precisão uma doença, os labs-on-a-chip podem se basear em vários métodos, incluindo o rastreamento químico de impressões digitais, para pescar através da grande mistura de substâncias tracejadas presente num amostra de saliva.

Note: "labs-on-a-chip" is a direct translation, as it's a term used in scientific and medical contexts. If you want to use a more idiomatic translation, you could say "microscópios em um chip" or "pratos de laboratório miniaturizados", which convey the idea of small-scale laboratory equipment.

source: You may have walked into that theater as an individual consumer, but if the theater does its job, you've walked out with a sense of yourself as part of a whole, as part of a community.
reference: Podemos ter entrado no teatro como um consumidor individual, mas, se o teatro fizer seu papel, saímos de lá com uma ideia de nós como parte de um todo, com parte de uma comunidade.
llama3:
Here is the translation:

Você pode ter entrado nesse teatro como um consumidor individual, mas se o teatro fez seu trabalho, você saiu daí com uma sensação de si mesmo como parte de um todo, como parte de uma comunidade.

Note: In Portuguese, "consumer" is translated as "consumidor", and "part of a whole" can be translated as "parte de um todo". The phrase "as part of a community" was kept literally to maintain the same meaning and nuance as in the original English text.

source: If you want to go beyond a tinkering, if you want to go beyond a hobby of robotics and really tackle the grand challenges of robotics through rigorous research, we need more than that.
reference: Se você quer ir além de ficar fuçando, se você quer ir além de um hobby de robótica e realmente atacar os grandes desafios da robótica através de pesquisa rigorosa nós precisamos de mais.

Se você quiser ir além de apenas brincar, se você quiser ir além de uma atividade recreativa de robótica e realmente enfrentar os grandes desafios da robótica por meio de pesquisas rigorosas, precisamos de mais do que isso.

Note: The translation is in Brazilian Portuguese. If you need it in European Portuguese (Portuguese from Portugal), I can make the necessary adjustments.

source: He lived up to his nickname "William the Conqueror" through a massive survey known as the Domesday Book, which recorded the population and ownership of every piece of land in England.
reference: Ele foi fiel ao seu apelido "William, o Conquistador" através de uma enorme pesquisa conhecida como Domesday Book, que contém a população e posse de cada pedaço de terra da Inglaterra.
llama3:

Note: I translated "William the Conqueror" to "Guilherme o Conquistador", as this is the common translation of his nickname in Portuguese.

source: On one of the days that we faced a line of hundreds of police officers pushing us back, pushing us off indigenous lands, there were those teenagers out on horseback across the plains.
reference: Em um dos dias que enfrentamos centenas de policiais nos obrigando a recuar e nos expulsando das terras indígenas, havia adolescentes a cavalo pelas planícies.

Here's the translation:

Numa dessas dias em que enfrentamos uma linha de centenas de policiais empurrando-nos para trás, empurrando-nos das terras indígenas, havia aqueles adolescentes a cavalo ao longo dos planaltos.

Note: I translated "plains" as "planaltos", which is the most common translation for this word in Portuguese. If you're looking for a more literal translation, "prairies" could also work. Let me know if you have any further questions!

source: Yeah, and the great thing is, if an earth wall is not needed anymore, it can go back to the ground it came from, turn into a garden, or get fully recycled without any loss of quality.
reference: Sim... e o incrível é que se uma parede de terra não é mais necessária, ela pode retornar ao chão de onde veio, virando um jardim, ou se reciclando completamente sem nenhuma perda de qualidade.
llama3:
Here's the translation:

Note: I translated "earth wall" as "muralha de terra", which is a common term in Portuguese to refer to a natural or artificial barrier made of soil. If you meant something else by "earth wall", please let me know and I'll be happy to adjust the translation!

source: We traveled high into the paramo, and as we crested the hills, we realized that the men were interpreting every single bump on the landscape in terms of their own intense religiosity.
reference: Nós viajamos longe, adentrando o Potomo, e a medida que percorriamos a crista dos montes, nós percebemos que os homens estavam interpretando cada pequena elevação da paisagem, em termos de sua própria intensa religiosidade.
llama3:
Here is the translation:

Viajamos alto no paramo e, ao atingirmos as colinas, nos demos conta de que os homens estavam interpretando cada uma das ondulações do terreno em termos da sua própria intensa religiosidade.

Note: "Paramo" is a specific type of high-altitude ecosystem in the Pyrenees and other mountain ranges. It's a beautiful word that doesn't have an exact equivalent in English, but I've kept it as it was to preserve the original meaning and context.

source: So this led full circle, in a strange way, to build these ideas into what we believe is the necessary future of human machine interface: the Spatial Operating Environment, we call it.
reference: E isso levou a uma situação, de uma maneira estranha, para construirmos essas ideias no que acreditamos ser o futuro necessário de interfaces homem-máquina, o espaço-ambiente operacional, nós o chamamos.
llama3:
Aí isso levou em um círculo cheio, de uma forma estranha, para construir essas ideias no que cremos ser o futuro necessário da interface homem-máquina: o Ambiente Operacional Espacial, chamamos-o assim.

Note:

* "So this" is translated to "Aí isso", as "so this" is an idiomatic expression that doesn't have a direct translation in Portuguese. The word "aí" is used to indicate a connection between the previous sentence and the following one.
* "full circle" was translated to "em um círculo cheio", as it's a common idiomatic expression that means to come back to where you started, but with new insights or understanding.
* "Spatial Operating Environment" was kept in English, as it's a technical term that doesn't have a direct translation in Portuguese. If the context requires a more natural translation, "Ambiente Operacional Espacial" could be used.
* "we call it" is translated to "chamamos-o assim", as "it" refers to the Spatial Operating Environment, and "chamamos-o" is the correct way to translate "we call it" in this context.

source: SD: So you may have heard of "spaghettification," where you fall into a black hole and the gravitational field on your feet is much stronger than on your head, so you're ripped apart.
reference: SD: Você deve ter ouvido falar em "espaguetificação", quando caímos em um buraco negro, e o campo gravitacional nos pés é muito mais forte do que na cabeça, então, somos despedaçados.

Here's the translation:

Note: In Portuguese, it's common to use the formal form (você) when addressing someone you don't know well or in a professional setting. If you want to use the informal form (tu), the translation would be:

source: So if we can help people in the forest enforce the rules that are there, then in fact we could eat heavily into this 17 percent and potentially have a major impact in the short term.
reference: Logo, se ajudarmos as pessoas da floresta a aplicar as leis existentes, enttão poderemos reduzir drasticamente os 17% e potencialmente ter um impacto maior, em curto prazo.

Here's the translation:

Português:

Se podemos ajudar as pessoas na floresta a implementar as regras que existem, então, de facto, poderíamos comer pesadamente nesse 17 por cento e potencialmente ter um impacto significativo no curto prazo.

Note: The word "enforce" was translated to "implementar", which is the most common translation in this context. "Eat heavily into" was translated to "comer pesadamente nesse", assuming that it means to make a significant reduction or withdrawal from something (in this case, the 17%). source: Where I ran into the most heat from this most recently was last year when South African runner, Caster Semenya, had her sex called into question at the International Games in Berlin.
reference: Onde me deparei com a maior agitação sobre isto recentemente foi no ano passado, com a corredora sul-africana Caster Semenya, quando o seu sexo foi posto em questão nos Jogos Internacionais em Berlim.
